title: sun readers 2020 britain themselves
story: With a strong Tory Government, many can’t wait to “get Brexit done”, as Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised.They are also concerned with our NHS, police, security, global warming and the environment.And they want action on housing and problems on the high street.Here,  readers tell KATE JACKSON of their visions for the year  and beyond . . .DAN ASPLEY, , and we MARIE from Warton, Warks, are parents to -year-old CALLIE who has a rare form of dwarfism called RCDP.Marie, , a sales ledger supervisor, says: “This time last year we were told we might lose Callie because her health was so bad.“But she’s a fighter and after months in hospital we were able to bring her home. Dan was already a full-time carer but in  I had to take six months off work so that we could share -hour care for Callie. We also had to give up our house.“For that reason our vision for  would be for The Sun’s Give It Back campaign to succeed and the Government to fund children’s social care properly.”“I hope it will happen this year, as soon as possible. I am sick of hearing about it.“I have two adopted children, aged two and five, and I want them to be happy and healthy. Perhaps I will adopt some more children.”Fashion accessory seller DEBBIE JECKELLS, , is from Colchester, Essex.She says: “Smaller businesses are struggling these days and I think people should use their local traders rather than the big shop that does everything.“Boris has said he will help smaller businesses and that will be welcomed.“I think things will get tougher for everyone and the economy is a worry.“The environment could be a problem too. I just want a better world for my grandchildren.”“I would end all austerity and the cuts. Everyday people like us seem to suffer the most.“In , I think we should be most concerned with the outcome of Brexit. It depends on what deal Boris can get for us.”LOUISE HARMAN, , is an account manager from Seaford, East Sussex who works in the medical industry.She says: “In the next ten years, it will be quite important to me knowing where pensions are going.“That is a bit of a minefield and I would like a bit more certainty from the Government, since they change the milestones.“The age of retirement was  when I was growing up but it is now creeping up. If they keep changing the milestones, I am going to be in trouble.”Barista and coffee shop owner OZQIN PORTO, , is from Walton-on-the-Naze, Essex.He says: “I want to see people happy and there has to be lots of jobs for young people.“I have many young people in my shop and I want them to be successful.“We need more help for autistic children than what is available at the moment.“Our children are the future and need more help.”EMILY BARTON, , is a charity worker from London.She says: “I wish there was a bit more equality in the world. It would be nicepeople were treated more equally.“I don’t think this will be possible under a Boris Johnson government, but we can certainly all try.“In the next decade, I think getting on the property ladder and buying a house seems sensible. Maybe even a family and kids.”RETIRED receptionist EILEEN WEBSTER is from Colchester, Essex.Eileen, , says: “I want peace all over the world and I want people to stop being mean to each other. Manners don’t cost a thing.“Climate change is the big issue facing the next generation.“When I think about the lives my great grandchildren will live, I feel sorry for them.”PAUL CONNETT, , of Ivybridge, Devon, runs a leather business.He says: “I would like Boris to reach a trade agreement with Europe which will be good for the UK. I think Boris will get one. He has such a majority now so he has a much bigger chance.“After an unsettling time in the UK, I hope things will become more settled and prosperous for us.”VANESSA PERKINS, , is from Colchester, Essex.The healthcare professional says: “The NHS needs more money. Boris has promised that, so I just hope that he does it.“My partner has cancer. He’s had immunotherapy and wouldn’t have made it to Christmas without it.“He only gets funding for two years as the treatment is so expensive.“He is working and he has contributed his whole le to the NHS. It needs more resources.”RETIRED maintenance engineer, DAVID CLOTHIER, , is from Newcastle.He says: “If I could change one thing I would get the homeless off the streets.“I have never seen so many. It is unbelievable, especially now when it is freezing cold.“I think people should be concerned with focusing on the health services, mental health and education.“I have recently had dealings with the NHS. It was a terrible experience.”KATHY FEDDER, , is a nurse from Erdington, Birmingham.She says: “I am most concerned about protecting the NHS and the education system.“Teachers are too stressed. They take work home with them and it’s too much.“The kids don’t learn that much in school. They aren’t made to think – they are just fed information.“Hopefully Boris won’t mess things up.”Salesman TOM KING, , from Bristol, said: “I’m trying to save for a house at the moment. I think they should build new homes, but onlythey are good quality.“I think new-build homes these days are pretty shocking. I know a lot of friends who have had some pretty bad experiences.“It’s not about churning out houses for the sake of it. It’s about building houses which are going to last so we are not in this predicament again.”Mum-of-two SHARON PLANT, , is a hair accessories designer from Newcastle.She says: “If I could change one thing I would put more money into the services – the police, ambulances, doctors.“We have a wonderful NHS up here but it also gets abused.“I hope the Government does something with the NHS. I have a son and daughter, aged  and , who want to go down the medical career route.”Lorry driver JOE VASZILKO, , is originally from Hungary and now lives in Erdington, Birmingham.He says: “There is a lot of mess everywhere. People throw their rubbish on the floor. I would change that. We should look after the environment more. There are bins – use them.“Everyone’s confidence has been affected by Brexit. We can’t see the light at the end of the tunnel at the moment.“We need to start growing and making our own products. And people have been living on benefits for too long now.”She says: “I wish people would respect each other more. I would like people to be nicer to each other on social media and not influence younger girls to act older than they are.“People should be concerned about technological advancements. Some of this progress is good but it could limit jobs and even social interaction.”LAWRENCE ADAH is from Nigeria and now lives in Fenham, Newcastle.The -year-old environmental engineering student says: “I’d like to see a policy that allows me to stay here and work for two years after I graduate.“I hope the Government improves the NHS and gives universities more funding towards research.“I want world leaders to take climate change more seriously too.”ANNA LUBECKA, , is a Polish-born children’s book designer who lives in East London.She says: “In the next ten years I want the Government to start making good plans for climate change.“I would like to see us building more green resources. I am working on a project about what Greta Thunberg is doing and hope children can see that message.“I am getting married next year so I would like happiness in le with my family.”Starbucks branch manager GULAM MOHIUDDIN, , from Poplar, East London, says: “The country needs to spend money where it feels the most threat, such as with terrorism.“Countries need to invest in education where those threats are, such as in the Middle East. I think only education can change the whole thing.“I was working here when the recent London Bridge attack happened. I was so scared. People want to feel safe.”WARANT officer ANDRE HILL, , from Horseheath, Cambs, says: “I am leaving the Army in February and I’ve applied for the police.“I would like more investment in the police and more officers on the streets. It would be better for me and for public safety, which is a main interestfor everybody.“There should be more concern with social media and people being brainwashed on there.”   Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brussels sprout jesus mary christmas
story: Sheila Freeman, , had an almighty shock when she noticed the holy resemblance as she was preparing the dinner.So she immediately popped the Nativity-shaped vegetable in the fridge for safekeeping. title: new decade improve politics
story: But let’s be frank. Things can only improve on the last four years of anger, ision and political paralysis.A period which should have been pivotal to our country saw it barely governed at all. That all changed at pm on December .Boris Johnson’s thumping election win gives us the greatest opportunity for radical renewal since at least .That means finally achieving Brexit  days from now and then, we hope, rapidly ­striking trade deals with Brussels and the world’s greatest economies.It means a dramatic, imaginative ­Budget to turbo-charge both those “left-behind” regions which voted Tory for the first time and the wider economy.We share too the  vision of our readers: For huge NHS investment to continue and a long-term social care solution be put in place.That tax breaks and rate cuts must renew our dilapidated High Streets and help small firms thrive and create jobs.That rough sleeping must be slashed, even ended. That wages must be driven up and food banks rendered redundant.That the Tories must continue striving for a cleaner environment without ­caving in to economy-wrecking panic.And we of course share the desire for a kinder, more united country — echoed by the open letter from faith, ­culture, sport and business leaders.The Sun is optimistic about that too.In fact we do not agree we have suffered a “decade of ision”. Yes, it was tough financially. But we were far from ided at, say, the  Olympics.The anger in our Parliament, offices, factories and homes was caused by Brexit, specically by some Remainers’ refusal to accept defeat, and by a Labour Party engulfed by the hostile hard-left.The Brexit heat is fast dissipating now. Boris’s triumph saw to that. Many Remainers are making their peace with it . . . and even seeing its opportunities.Which leaves but one obstacle to the national healing.No one has done more to ide us than Jeremy Corbyn, his thuggish, often anti-Semitic followers and his obnoxious media apologists.Their relentless hatred and dishonest demonisation of opponents toxied both political discourse and Labour’s election fortunes.Yet none of the contenders to replace Corbyn grasps this reality: They can remain a Twitter-obsessed, Tory-hating clique of middle-class Marxist posers calling each other “comrade” but disconnected from working people.Or be viable, mainstream contenders for Government. But not both.Will they make the right choice  It’s January , , and we live in hope.We are far more sure that Britain, fully independent for the first time in  years, will enjoy a golden decade in the ’s.Happy New Year to you all! Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: greta thunberg shift opinions
story: Thanks to the -year-old Swedish climate change campaigner many more of us are eco-warriors these days. Whichever box we ticked in the election, millions of us vote green with our lestyles.A recent survey of Sun readers showed  per cent recognise climate change is real and that  per cent of us worry more about our environmental impact now than they did five years ago.And  per cent of Sun readers want to make their habits greener still.Some of them make their voices heard.Retired receptionist Eileen Webster, , says “climate change is the big issue facing the next generation”, while Anna Lubecka, , demands new PM Boris Johnson, “start making good plans for climate change”.Attitudes to environmentalism have shted so much that being green is now no longer the preserve of lentil-munching hippies and Swampy, it is totally mainstream.No trendy bar would now dare put plastic straws in their cocktails.We’ve all got used to carrying Love Island-style water bottles and happily adopted reusable coffee cups. This year they pulled off a plastic-free Glastonbury, despite a few hiccups.We’ve long stopped grumbling about taking our own bags to the supermarket and got used to stuffing our pockets with them when we leave the house.So now in England, the average person uses less than a tenth of the number of single-use plastic bags than we did five years ago. Only around ten a year, compared to  in .As electric cars have improved, we’ve all been seduced — and not just by Tesla’s new “bulletproof” Cybertruck. Overall, demand for electric cars has jumped, with the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders finding that this November alone electric car sales leaped by . per cent, with more than three times as many new battery-electric vehicles registered as in the same month in .Nowhere  is it clearer that green has become the new black than in fashion, where criticism of fast fashion has led to trends for vintage, second hand and renting rather than buying.On the high street, companies such as HM have launched their “conscious collection” , fashion bible Vogue has championed sustainable designs, while French President Emmanuel Macron’s “fashion pact” — presented at the G summit and intended to make the industry more sustainable — has been signed by more than  brands, including Nike, Zara and Gap.All these changes prove how far we have come and the impact Greta has had.Hearing her, strong and calm, on Radio ’s Today programme this week, what struck me is that now another change is needed.This time a sht not in our actions, but in how we approach the environmental debate.It’s not beliefs but attitudes that need to change. Until now, environmental issues have been too isive.Butwe want real change we’ve got to move beyond blame.It puts people off environmental issues when campaigners hector and shame them.When wealthy celebrities such as Sir David Attenborough criticise normal people for taking holidays with cheap flights, or actress Emma Thompson jets back from America to harass normal people driving to work.In the same way Extinction Rebellion threatens to lose potential supporters when it starts fights with commuters trying to board their morning train or cause mayhem in central London.The real danger is that by being so aggressive, these green campaigners risk putting people off.Greta seems to know this. She is much calmer than she used to be when speaking in public.Rather than getting angry or emotional, instead she has stressed the importance of just, “listening to the scientists”.As usual, we could learn from her.The reality is most people want to be green.We are all concerned about global warming, pollution in the seas and the kind of planet we are creating for our grandkids. But you can’t shame people into doing something.Diesel drivers — especially White Van Man — shouldn’t be harassed just for getting to work. I’m sure they would buy more environmentally friendly vehiclesthey could afford to.Likewise, no one should be shamed for taking a flight — who knows what other measures they might be taking, such as living in a carbon neutral home What the planet needs least is more fighting. Instead we need grown-up debate.The answer to the climate crisis isn’t to criticise each other — it’s to work together to make real change. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: leaders call uk heal divided society
story: The representatives of some of the country’s biggest organisations want a “decade of reconnection” after years of bitter Brexit rows.In an open letter, they observe “our country feels more fragmented than any of us would like” and say it falls to all of us to do something about it.The leaders say we should start by reaching out to one person we do not know or from whom we have drted apart.Their letter adds: “While our politics and media have become more polarised we, as people, have not. There is much that we share with each other.”The clarion call has been backed by Sir Hugh Robertson, of the British Olympic Association, Glastonbury festival boss Emily Eavis, Dame Carolyn Fairbairn from the CBI and Matt Hyde, of The Scout Association.The letter has also been signed by the Young Vic theatre’s artistic director Kwame Kwei­Armah, Mike Sharrock of the British Paralympic Association — and the former heads of the Leave and Remain campaigns, Matthew Elliott and Will Straw.Church leaders, union bosses and charities also joined the call for unity.It comes as surveys have shown more than two thirds of the population are angrier about politics and society than before the referendum.A fth admit they often or always feel lonely despite eight in ten saying people from dferent backgrounds get on well.The leaders’ letter calls on Brits to “reach out to just one person we don’t know, or from whom we have drted apart”.It adds: “Every institution, too — not just government but education, business, sport, civic society and faith — should play its part in helping bridge social ides.“Today is about a small first step that we can all take — to leave behind ision and begin our decade of reconnection.”Imam Qari Asim, chair of the Mosques and Imams National Advisory Board, warned that growing apart breeds fear of those who we do not know or appear dferent.He said: “The start of a new decade offers us a moment of change and of hope — that we can all reach out and find a connection with someone new.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pope francis lashes worshipper arm st peters square
story: The -year-old was on his way to visit a nativity scene in Vatican Citys central plaza when the woman grabbed his hand and yanked him towards her.He had reached over a barrier to touch a child and had already turned to walk away when he was pulled back.The visibly-shocked pontf stumbled slightly as he moved back towards the barrier and appeared to be in some pain.He then scolded the woman verbally before slapping her hand twice when she still refused to let go.Security guards then moved in to pry the woman off him.The woman had made the sign of the cross as the Pope walked towards her, and was trying to talk to him as she held his hand, although it is not clear what she was saying.The Pope has now apologised over the incident, saying he set a bad example to his millions of followers.He was later filmed continuing to shake hands with worshippers and kissing the cheek of a baby passed to his guards by its mother.At the New Years Eve evening service at St Peters Basilica, the Pope told the congregation to practice solidarity and to build bridges, not walls.On Christmas Eve, he said the light of Christmas should be allowed to counter the darkness of human hearts, mentioning in particular unrest in Ukraine, Venezuela, Syria, and a number of countries in Africa.He also called for compassion for migrants forced by conflicts and economic hardship to emigrate in the hope of a secure le.He said that after perilous journeys, they are often find themselves before walls of indference in places where they might have hoped for a dignied le.The New Years incident is not the first time the Pope has rebuffed affection by the faithful.In March, he was filmed repeatedly pulling away his hand as followers made to kiss his ring during a visit to Italys Holy House of Loreto basilica.Vatican spokesman Alessandro Gisotti later explained the footage, saying: The Holy Father told me that the motivation was very simple: hygiene.He wants to avoid the risk of contagion for the people, not for him.

story: Thousands of partygoers donned bright and tight outfits as they hit the bars and clubs across the UK to mark the arrival of  last night.Revellers dressed in roaring s style to mark the new s decade while others slapped on bright wigs and dresses for the new year.Many gallant lads were pictured helping out female friends - giving them piggy backs as respite from their towering heels.From Leeds to Blackpool, groups of friends were pictured going into the new decade with a bang as firework shows were sent spinning into the sky across the cities.But as the night wore on, some smiles slid slightly as pals helped each other limp home after the raucous night.However, it wasnt all fun and games as the night descended into chaos for some Brits.Some were pictured being taken away by cops as the night got out of hand - including in Leeds.In London,  people were arrested as police patrolled the capitals celebrations.Among those taken into custody by cops by am, three people were arrested for being drunk and disorderly, while another was arrested for possession of a lock kne.Another two were arrested for possession of drugs and one on affray.They have since been taken to central London police stations.Meanwhile, officers were rushed to a South East Home just after midnight on reports of a fight at a house party.Three teen boys were found with stab injuries at the Casewick Road home.Their condition is not believed to be le-threatening.Three people were arrested on suspicion of attempted murder and taken to a south London police station where they remain in custody.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: york set to be the first uk city to ban all private car journeys in bid to be carbon neutral by 2030
story: In radical new proposals the city council is looking to stop all non essential car journeys taking place within the city walls by .The idea follows the lead taken by Bristol City Council in November which agreed to ban diesel cars from entering the city centre by .York is aiming to become carbon neutral by  -  years sooner than the UKs national target.More than  , people live in and around the city which also attracts millions of tourist each year.Councillors have acknowledged they will not be able to achieve the goal unless they take dficult and ambitious steps.According to York Press Labour councillor Jonny Crawshaw said the ban was not aimed to stop people from visiting the city or to stop residents from owning a car.He said: This is about reducing and removing non-essential car journeys across the whole city, whilst improving the range and attractiveness of alternative travel options.Fewer cars on York’s roads would enable faster, more reliable public transport from the suburbs and villages into the city centre.Fewer cars on the roads would make cycling feel safer and more viable option for more people.The plans were approved by the council who will now look  for a way to implement the ban over the next three years.They will also look to stop more non-essential car journeys on roads at the citys schools at pick-up and drop-off time.Mr Crawshaw added those who rely on car travel such as disabled residents would be exempt from the ban. Buses would also be exempt.

title: what is national minimum wage uk
story: But what is it now and what will it increase to The National Minimum Wage is currently the amount workers under , but of school-leaving age, are entitled to.The first National Minimum Wage was set in  by the Labour government.Before that, no official rate existed although trade unions battled hard to fight their workers corner.The National Minimum Wage was re-branded to the National Living Wage in  for those over .In April , the National Living Wage was increased by  pence-an-hour to £..And in December , Sajid Javid announced a Living Wage increase of p to £., giving a boost to all those over .But the great news is that there are increases across the board for all age groups and those on apprenticeship schemes.Heres the latest national limits as of April  that are legally binding:With the increase on April , , these will now stand at:Anyone who thinks they are not getting the National Living Wage or National Minimum Wage should complain to their employer in the first instance.If this does not get anywhere, the next step is to take the complaint to HMRC who will investigate.Chancellor Sajid Javid has announced there will be an increase in the National Minimum Wage from £. to £. an hour in April.The .% rise is double the rate of average annual wage growth and also twice the current rate of inflation, as well as the legal minimum’s biggest cash rise ever since it came into force in .The increase in minimum wage will deliver an extra £ a year into the pockets of almost three million who earn it.Those who are self-employed, voluntary workers, company directors and family members who live in the home of the employer and do household chores do not qualy for either rate.There is no dference in pay for those that live in London compared to where.The only discrepancy is for people working in agriculture or horticulture.Workers already employed before October , , are entitled to the pay set under their contract of employment.

No, some viewers of the BBCaposs coverage of the midnight fireworks around the London Eye saw a hidden message in the display about the outgoing Labour leader. And London Mayor Sadiq Khan has been accused of planting political messages in the display in previous years. Last year the display appeared to have an anti-Brexit tint to it - We Are Your Friends, Stay and Donapost Leave Me Alone were among songs chosen for the -minute soundtrack, which featured artists from Ireland, France, Sweden and where. You see, as well as being an anthem beloved of the many, not the few, Seven Nation Army is frequently sung at sporting events.  One such sporting event, the football European Championship - or Euro  - is being held in London this year. The song was also sandwiched between two other sporting anthems. Before it was Three Lions by Baddiel, Skinner and the Lightning Seeds - which was originally written as Englandaposs anthem for Euro apos, the last time the tournament was held here.

Since ditching the high calorie diet he has shed nine stone.He changed his ways when his dad, Jason, , suffered a stroke and sepsis , and was left fighting for his le.Now  months on, Brandon from Wakefield, West Yorkshire, is a buff st with huge muscles and aspirations to compete at World’s Strongest Man. Personal trainer Brandon said: When I set out all I knew was I wanted to be as strong as I possibly could and I didn’t care about the effects that had on my body. “I had a passion to get strong and was inspired by Eddie Hall and the bodybuilders I followed online. “I took on board what they did and caved in to the pressures to eat loads of food. “I had an obsession to get strong and wanted to go all out.  “My mentality was to eat as much as I physically could, regardless of how fat it made me. “I was willing to do anything to be the strongest and I started eating at least , calories a day. “It made me feel awful but I was getting really strong. Brandon used to weight st a was a ‘fit and active’ teenager and professional rugby player with Castleford Tigers when he was . But he fell out of love with the game and turned his attention to weightlting, and started piling on the pounds in .  He read about Worldaposs Strongest Man Eddie Hall, and how the st champion ate , calories a day. While doing a six-day-a-week weightlting routine, Brandon went from eating a regular diet to gorging between , and , calories a day. In an average day he would eat eight rashers of bacon, four slices of toast, four eggs and an ice cream protein powder smoothie for breakfast. story: NewsDoing it with someone  is key to sticking to healthy lestyle, study showsA study of , adults found two in five plan to try a dferent diet or fitness routine in  - but its better to buddy upyou dont want to lose your wayShareCommentsByAlice Hughes:,  JAN NewsWhen youre doing it with your buddy, everythings easier " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBrits are more likely to stick to a healthy lestyle changetheyaposre doing it with someone . A study of , adults found two in five plan to try a dferent diet or fitness routine in , with  per cent getting a buddy to do it with them. As a result of getting fit and healthy with a friend,  per cent agree they are more likely to stick with a new plan. And one in four believe they burn off more calories when working out with a friend than they do alone. A third of those polled in the study, commissioned by WW - Weight Watchers Reimagined, even admitted they would give up sooner without the help of another person to keep them going. Half put the success with a partner down to feeling more motivated,  per cent enjoy planning meals together and a quarter prefer having someone to exercise with. But the average adult admitted to falling out of a gym routine after  weeks and slipping up around eight weeks into a diet. Zoe Grfiths, global director of nutrition at WW: Itaposs interesting to see how much of a positive influence a partner can have on Brits sticking to diet plans and fitness routines. Whether itaposs giving up something together such as chocolate, or hitting milestones together like five or k runs, it always helps having someone  going through the same emotions. Youaposre more likely to stick to a wellness commitment or diet when you do it with someone  you can lean on for support and motivation. It helps you to be more open and honest about your diet, makes activities like working out more enjoyable and softens the fear of failure. The study also found two thirds are planning on getting healthy with their other half, while a fth are taking the plunge with a friend. An eighth are even attempting to make a lestyle change with their colleague. A third of those polled admitted they usually need to be motivated when sticking to a health plan, with their partner considered to be the best at giving them a boost when they need it. More than a fthalso said itaposs easier to be activeit means spending time with a relative or buddy. And one in four find following a plan with a fitness partner both confidence boosting and fun.  A further  per cent saidtheyaposre following an exercise regime with a companion they wouldnapost quit eventhey wanted to - because they wouldnapost want to be the one to let the team down. Similarly, three in  admitted to cancelling on a gym buddy in the past, which left  per cent feeling guilty and more than a quarter feeling lazy. When it comes to eating, one in four prefer meal-planning with someone  rather than going it alone and  per cent admitted itaposs most dficult to stick to a healthy diet when eating out with friends.

title: flourishing towns show lots celebrate
story: NewsFlourishing towns show there is lots to celebrate despite high street job cutsAs we enter the New Year, the Mirror – which is championing town centres with our High Street Fightback campaign – highlights three of the many inspirational places that are standard-bearers for how it can be doneShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of BusinessJeremy ArmstrongAdam Aspinall:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsShop owner Laura Armstrong, from Strut Menswear in Belper Derbyshire, who has been shortlisted for the Daily Mirror backed High Street Hero Award " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAn estimated , shop jobs were lost last year, with warnings another , could go in  unless urgent action is taken. But it’s not all doom and gloom. Despite an onslaught of online competition, some high streets are thriving. As we enter the New Year, the Mirror – which is championing town centres with our High Street Fightback campaign – highlights three of the many inspirational places that are standard-bearers for how it can be done. Buzzing as we have the best community spirit It’s am on a Friday and Belper’s main street is bustling. The town lies at the heart of the Derwent Valley Mills World Heritage Site. Industrial pioneer Jedediah Strutt built one of the world’s first water powered cotton spinning mills here in . But, like many towns, it has had its fair share of challenges in recent years. Chocolate maker Thorntons and a clothes company closed their factories in the early s, and textile maker Courtaulds shut its plant in , with hundreds of job losses. But you couldn’t tell the impactyou took a walk round the Derbyshire town’s centre now.  There is hardly an empty shop, and along with a few chain stores – including Boots, Wilko, Card Factory and Hays Travel – there are an array of independents. They include two butchers and a greengrocer, gt shops, plus the wonderful looking Ritz Cinema. But above all, there is a genuine buzz about the place. Chris Gregory, co-owner of the fantastic Beaurepaire Patisserie cafe, echoes many the Mirror spoke to about why the high street is doing well. He said: “It’s got the best community spirit. Whenever an event is put on it’s really well attended.” Chris, , who is born and bred in the town, and his partner have another shop in Belper and added his sister plans to open an interiors store here. He said: “The shops don’t become available that often and go really quickly.” Julia Greening has had her furniture and interiors shop, Sundial, for  years. She appealed for people not to take local shops for granted, saying: “If you let shops go, they are lost for ever.” One reason for Belper’s success is a band of business owners who have worked tirelessly to promote the place. They include Laura Armstrong, who runs menswear shop Strut, and chairs the Love Belper committee. The Love Belper website has been a big hit, while its use of social media has drawn visitors in from further afield. Laura, , said: “We have people coming from Derby because they say it’s dying on its feet.” Laura, who praised Belper town council for its support, said trading for her is hard, despite all the efforts. It proves how even high streets that are pulling out all the stops still need people’s backing to flourish. Transformed after tough times  Five years ago Treorchy was just another part of the Valleys struggling to come to terms with the collapse of big industry. But take the time to stroll down the high street now and you realise an inspiring transformation has slowly taken place. Treorchy has nearly  shops. Whereas a decade ago many were struggling or empty, the town now boasts an occupancy rate of %. The vast majority of these businesses are independent and most are run by women, giving the high street a refreshingly cosy vibe. This transformation has been the result of a lot of hard work by business leaders here who realised action had to be taken. They came together under the stewardship of Treorchy Chamber of Trade chairman Adrian Emmett, who has watched the membership soar from  to . The traders have launched a series of initiatives, such as the Visit Treorchy website, to attract people to invest. Adrian explained that, underpinning it all, is a “circular market” in which each business prioritises buying from each other. He said: “Towns like this did not have the confidence. They needed to believe in themselves and we needed to change the mindset. I like to think we’re doing that and the confidence is back.  “I am so proud of how much we have achieved.” Holly Thomas, , who is the very proud owner of the Number  gt shop, said: “I think the reason it has worked is because we have all come together.” Zoe Davies, , who has run the Fusion beauty parlour for  years, is delighted by the way Treorchy’s high street has been transformed. She said: “It was worrying at one point when you saw all the empty shops but now it is thriving and it is nice to be part of it.” Plenty to smile about in the friendliest port  The number of people visiting the award-winning shops here has rocketed. Civic chiefs from across the country go to Amble, Northumberland, to learn the secrets of its success. It was shortlisted in  for the Great British High Street champion award after winning the coastal community category three years ago.  Traders in what is known as “the friendliest port” are seeing the benefits of the “Harbour Village”, part of a £.million Government investment. A £, national bird sculpture trail is to come. The town square’s beautul war memorial is a reminder of Amble’s proud history the Cock  Bull micro pub shows it is moving with the times. That is where the cock and bull ends there is real success here. Queen Street is at the heart of it.

title: raucous new years eve revellers
story: Raucous New Years Eve revellers bring carnage to streets as they ring in There were spirited celebrations - and some punch-ups and drama as New Years Eve revellers partied into the early hours in places such as Birmingham, Manchester, Leeds, Cardf, Swansea and BlackpoolShareCommentsByChris Kitching:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN News Thousands of spirited New Years Eve revellers took to the streets to ring in  and give a wild send-off to the last decade.Partygoers spent the night in clubs and bars across Britain and the festivities carried on well into the early hours after the clock struck She got breathless walking around the house and found it hard to keep up with her three ­children, Dillon, , Keigan, , and Lois, nine. “My size made me miserable and I always felt like I was on the sidelines of le,” she says. “I wasn’t really getting as involved as I should because my size was holding me back.” Unbeknown to Julie, her mother’s biggest hope before her death at just , was for Julie to lose weight. But for a year, the opposite happened as she ate through her grief. Julie finally decided to join her local Slimming World group with her two sisters, Lindsey, , and Katie, . And, in  months, she had lost an ­incredible eight stone and was down to a size . After hitting her target weight on Christmas Eve  – st lb – she got a touching message from her mother’s friend, Helen, to tell her how proud she was – and how worried her mother had been. Julie, an early years’ practitioner from Oldmeldrum, Aberdeenshire, said: “It was awful to hear that Mum had been so worried about me – especially in those last few months – but I know how proud she would be to see how well I’ve done. “It really has changed my le. Instead of just surviving, I’m finally living!” The mum of three admits she had always struggled with her weight and, as a teenager, was two dress sizes bigger than her friends and a size . But it wasn’t until she met her husband John, now , in April , that she really began to pile on the pounds.  She says: “We’d have nights in with ­takeaways, go out for meals or have friends over and snack on crisps and wine.” The couple married in June . However, in the three years they had been together, Julie, who is ft in, had gone from a size  to a size . And the problem only got worse, in , when Vera was diagnosed with breast cancer, and Julie moved into her home to care for her. She says: “When Mum moved into a hospice in August , I’d grab breakfast on the run so I could be with her, then we’d have tea and cake in the day. It became easier to grab a McDonald’s when I headed home. And rather than eating a balanced diet, I just ate rubbish.” Vera passed away in November , but Julie’s weight continued to spiral, and she was soon a size . “I could barely walk up the stairs without getting out of breath and did absolutely no exercise,” she explains. “So, when my sisters joined Slimming World in January , I went too because I didn’t want to miss out!” And soon she saw a huge dference. “I started to think more about what I was putting in my body” Julie says. “Instead of grabbing the easiest thing, like a jar of sauce to chuck on some spaghetti, I’d make it and know what ingredients I was putting in. I naturally found myself eating more fruit and veg and the weight was just falling off – it was so easy.”

story: NewsopinionIf someone has to tell you that its "just a normal argument", the chances are it probably isntDomestic abuse spikes at Christmas and most victims refuse to believe it is happening to them. Make  the year you listen to your own voice, and not theirsShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JAN Newsopinion" to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPerhaps Christmas is the one time of year you think is safe - with family around, traditions to fulfil, and witnesses. But itaposs more likely the festive season makes you extra-vigilant. Keeping an eye on how much they drink. Worrying what your loved ones will notice. Hiding the cost of things. Terried that now thereaposs witnesses.  Victims of domestic abuse are usually the last ones to realise it. You will probably tell people,it comes up, that someone who stays with their abuser is an idiot. You genuinely believe this, because you do not know much about it. Whether you are having your money taken, your liberty restricted, or your peace of mind destroyed, you are far too close to see it properly. You canapost get perspectiveyouaposre not at peace. Calls to police about domestic incidents spike at Christmas. The combination of alcohol, financial and family pressure, and being in close quarters adds to the pressure which you have got used to dealing with - like a temperamental, dysal cooker that will burn the roast,you donapost know the trick of how to close the door just so. You might think that knowing such tricks, spotting the problems early and moving quickly to deflect them, makes you a great chef. Actually what it means is youaposve got a knackered cooker.  A victim calls the police every  seconds for help. According to the Office of National Statistics, last year there were .m domestic abuse incidents and crimes recorded by police. Only  in every  such reports ever leads to an arrest. And the first time somebody asks for help is, on average, the th time something that is not normal has happened to them.They will not get effective help until it has happened  times.On average, victims live with their abuser for  or  years before they leave. Some for decades. Two thirds of them will try to leave  or  times in the year before they finally manage it. But not you. Because youaposve got this.  You are strong. You know how to fix it, and what sets it off. You know not to wear those clothes, not to talk about those things, not to ask that question. You know when to send the kids to your mumaposs, when to say sorry, when to go limp because thataposs the quickest way to make it end.You know itaposs normal to argue. You know itaposs normal for things to get a bit out of hand. Itaposs normal that someone with problems - perhaps drugs, or booze, issues at work or in their past - needs you to understand them better. They need YOUR help.Maybe the first time you said sorry it felt wrong, but it was the only way to make things calm again. Maybe you now think that youaposre always the one to blame. But you are strong, so you stay. Even though it is not normal to have to convince yourself to do that. It is not normal for blood to be spilled on bedsheets. Itaposs not normal for the neighbours to be so alarmed they call the police. Itaposs not a normal argument,you are down by one bedside lamp at the end of it and someoneaposs had to go to AE to get patched up. It IS entirely normal for the person responsible to tell you that itaposs fine, that you made them do it, thatonly you donapost do that again they wonapost get so angry, that you need to apologise to them and thataposs the only way to make up. It is normal for them to want, and expect, and need all the sympathy thataposs going.And itaposs entirely normal that you believe them. They use the same words and phrases our parents use, likeyou do that again... They play on the fact you love them. They tell you they love you, or perhaps theyaposve stopped telling you that, because it makes you work harder to hear it. It is normal that you bend. It is not normal that you break your spine doing it.  When was the last time you did not worry about what would happen at Christmas  When was the last time you worked, went out, had fun, flirted, relaxed, or laughed like you used to  When was the last time you talked about your relationship to someone , and didnapost lie about it  It is not normal to worry what the person who is supposed to love you will do next. It is not normal to hide the truth, wear clothes that cover it up, or pray the family donapost notice how afraid you are. You are right. Someone who can put up with all of this is very strong, and capable of deep and abiding love. It is the person doing it to you who is weak.  They are the one who feels something in their le is out of control - anything, from their age to their job to an addiction. Perhaps thereaposs an unexpected pregnancy, or a bereavement. But one way or another, they havenapost quite got a grip on things. So they hold on to you a bit tighter. At the start itaposs just a hug. But over time, you find it harder to breathe, to be you. You change, bend, accommodate, compromise, and every time you do they ask for more. Itaposs never enough. Something will always make them cross again, and you have to bend further. If youaposre lucky it will stop all by itself. Butitaposs not fixed itaposll come back. Do you really want to spend the next  years - hell,  minutes - waiting to seeit will happen again  Last year the police recorded  domestic homicides. Thataposs more than one person, every day, killed by someone they live with. One fth of people aged  to  have personal experience of domestic abuse. Itaposs horribly normal, what youaposre going through. But you are going through it. And itaposs possible to get out.

Last December Becky Dell was inspired by the David Attenborough show Blue Planet to do her bit to help the environment. The Londoner decided to only buy food, drink and basic toiletries in . Writing on Twitter Becky said she watched, with shame plastic floating in the oceans and wondered how much was hers. So, aside from mascara and moisturiser, Becky did not buy anything she didnapost need. That meant no clothes, shoes, presents, other makeup, hair products, jewellery, bags, decorations, anything disposable, plants, flowers, house items etc. And the money that she saved from not splashing out would be given to a selection of charities and grassroots organisations. Becky says she ended up saving and donating £,.. But there were times when emergencies meant she had to buy something. On Twitter she said: I bought  things during the year, for example, a new jacket when my zip broke at - up a mountain, brr, a couple of essential things for my very elderly cats and a couple of essential house items. Each one made me really annoyed! And friends and family understood her challenge and supported Beckyaposs decision, with the thrty musical director making presents herself instead. And there were some things she really missed. Becky wrote: The thing I missed the most was buying plants and flowers, I love nature and found that hard. Solutions were growing flowers from seedand getting cuttings from friends . I now have rhubarb growing!!  At first, she said, it was quite easy: January to August was surprisingly easybut it got WAY hard from August, as clothes started running out and however much I darned my socks they just stayed holey. It got easier in December as I could start counting down. After  months of austere living the first thing Becky plans on splashing out on is socks, plants, some nice tea towels and a tea strainer.

Bulgarian born Baba Vanga has been dubbed the aposNostradamus of the Balkansapos for her predictions. Despite dying  years ago, those with a keen interest in mysticism continue to revere Babaaposs work, which some claim looks forward to  - the year she believed the universe will end. Right before her death at the age of  she made a series of predictions for the year . The most startling revelation is that Vladamir Putin and Donald Trumpaposs lives are in danger. The Russian president could reach the end of his mortal coil thanks to an assassination attempt made from within the Kremlin. Almost as dramatically, the US president will fall ill with a mysterious illness which will leave him deaf and with a brain tumour. Those with long memories may remember Baba foretold that Putin and Trumpaposs lives would be in danger last year, suggesting some kind of cosmic rollover.  Another recurrent theme in her predictions has been the destruction of Asia. Baba foresaw that “a big wave will cover the shore and people will disappear underwater” in what some interpreted as the destruction of Thailand by a huge tsunami in . The outlook in  is equally as bleak, with more tsunamis and earthquakes scheduled to hit the continent. A meteorite is also predicted to fall on Russia.  Perhaps the most ominous prediction of the clairvoyant was that the European continent could reach the end of its existence at the hands of Muslim extremists The Bulgarian suggested that extremists would use an arsenal of chemical weapons against Europeans”. Supporters of Baba are keen to emphasise how spot on she has been, with % accurate a phrase that regularly crops up in fan forums. According to baba-vanga, the figure is drawn from research conducted by Professor Georgi Lozanov - a former director of the Bulgarian Institute of Suggestology. Others point to her past successes as proof that she had foresight beyond that of a typical human.  In  she guessed that America would be hit by two apossteel birdsapos in a terror attack, in what was later interpreted as a reference to  . She said: Horror, horror! The American brothers will fall after being attacked by the steel birds. The wolves will be howling in a bush, and innocent blood will be gushing. Babaaposs big breakthrough had come a year earlier however, when she accurately predicted the sinking of Russian submarine the Kursk. Before cancelling Christmas and ordering a nuclear bunker however, readers should know that some questions remain around Baba and her predictions - some of which have been proved to be way off the mark.  Her prophecy that Europe would cease to exist by  was clearly wrong, unless seen through an incredibly generous Brexiteer lense. Babaaposs suggestion that the  FIFA World Cup final would be played between two teams beginning with the letter aposbapos was equally wrong. The nuclear war pencilled in for the years  to  also failed to materialise. Perhaps more damning is the seemingly non-existent nature of her prophecies. While Baba may have spoken or written down her predictions in Bulgarian, no credible version is available to view. According to a  Washington Post investigation, the few prophecies that can be traced back to their origins appear to come from Russian social media. title: national organisation thanks dundee mum for breast milk donation after seeing tele story
story: A national organisation has thanked a young Dundee mum for donating breast milk, after seeing an article on the Tele website.Shelby O#Shea decided to give back to Dundee#s Ninewells Hospital after medics saved her daughter Maëva Aaliyah#s le.Shelby had a brush with death for both her and Maëva after she suffered from pre-eclampsia.The incident has inspired Shelby to make a New Year#s resolution to help others as much as she possibly can.Shelby, , from Lochee, gave birth to her baby on December  after an emergency Cesarean section at Ninewells.The lives of both mum and daughter were at risk and Maëva was delivered within an hour of Shelby going into hospital.She was born weighing only lbs one oz but apart from initial support with her breathing she was fit and well and healthy and has since gone from strength-to-strength, although she won#t be allowed out of hospital until some time in January.Dundee mum donates her own breast milk to the hospital that saved her baby" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp new-mum-donates-her-own-breast-milk-to-hospital-that-saved-her-baby embed # secretEIYjHPlj" data-secret"EIYjHPlj" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"Shelby too has made a quick recovery and decided to try to give something back to the hospital and support other mums and babies at the same time.She said that she was lucky to be producing a lot of milk to feed Maeva, so much in fact that she reckons she has some to spare.She said: #I have so much milk that another little baby could benefit from.#Seeing Maëva so small, premature and relying on my milk to survive more than anything it#s truly inspired me.#I’d love to help another baby in Maëva#s position whose mummy can’t give them that benefit of their own milk.#My  resolution is to make a dference to as many lives  as possible and give all I can to everyone I can help.#Le is far too short, you never know when your time is up, so make every day count and most importantly make a dference in the world any chance you get, it’s the littlest things that mean the most.#Commenting on the article on Facebook, a spokeswoman from Milk Bank Scotland, which is based in Glasgow#s NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde, said: #Thanks for the lovely story and article.#It’s so great to hear of your success in providing breast milk for both your own baby and to the milk bank.#The Scotland-wide donor milk bank service was officially launched in June .It benefits more than  of the most vulnerable babies a year, allowing them to be fed breastmilk for a longer period of time to reduce their health risks associated with being sick and premature.It will also help babies whose mothers have early feeding challenges, as they are able to get access to the donor breastmilk.The Scottish Donor Milk Bankcollects, screens, stores, processes and distributes donor breast milkto be fed to another mother’s child.All requests for donor milk from all neonatal units across Scotland are met.Donor milk is transported safely from donors homes to the DMB and from there to neonatal units across Scotland by the Glasgow Children’s Charity Volunteer Drivers.

title: poll should the jim mclean statue be outside dundee uniteds ground or in the city centre
story: He was the mercurial mastermind who led Dundee United to their only Premier Division title and memorable runs in European competition.Now, with the news the funding target has been reached for a permanent statue in honour of Jim McLean has been reached, there has been some discussion about where it should be placed.While for many, the natural, and indeed only home for the sculpture is either outside or wtihin the hallowed gates of Tannadice Park, home of Dundee United, where McLean has a stand named in his honour.However, Tele columnist John Brown has suggested that the statue be situated in the city centre, perhaps in City Square, for all visitors to Dundee to see.At other Scottish football grounds, statues to club icons tend to be positioned outside the grounds themselves.At Ibrox, a tribute to John Greig is situated outside the Bill Struth Main Stand at Ibrox.In , former Aberdeen and Scotland manager had a statue placed outside Manchester United#s ground, Old Trafford, the club where he found his most success.Statues of United#s #Holy Trinity# of George Best, Denis Law and Bobby Charlton were unveiled in  by Ferguson.Indeed, Ferguson, while a huge rival of McLean#s when their teams locked horns at either Tannadice or Pittodrie in the s, were close friends off the field.Mr Ferguson was one of the many in the footballing fraternity to give their backing to the statue of Jim McLean being commissioned, recording a short video message endorsing the campaign.Let’s make it happen pic WogjfKZfmdash Jim McLean Tribute Steering GroupMarch , McLean famously oversaw a - at the Camp Nou to beat Barcelona and progress to the semi-final of the Uefa Cup in  .However, sadly for United, they would go on to lose in the final against IFK Gothenburg, having defeated Mönchengladbach in the semi-finals.The Dundee United board made McLean a director in  four years later he became chairman and managing director, while still remaining the manager.He retained those joint responsibilities until stepping down as manager in July , after a reign of almost  years. He remained as chairman after resigning as manager, stepping down from this role in October .He went on to be honoured in  by having the Jim McLean Fair Play Stand named after him.But what do you think  Should the Jim McLean statue be positioned in or outside Tannadice, or in the city centre, for all visitors to the city to see Please vote in our poll below.

title: aberdeen arts company invited to shared ideas for revamped union terrace gardens
story: A visual arts company could be invited to take part in discussions to utilise space in the revamped Union Terrace Gardens.Contemporary arts venue Peacock Visual Arts, which is located in the city’s Castle Street, put forward its own project to open an arts centre in the area around a decade ago at the same time as Sir Ian Wood’s £ million vision was unveiled for the space.However, both were rejected, with council bosses later devising their own multi-million-pound scheme to transform the historic gardens, with construction beginning on the project earlier this year.New walkways, pavilions, event space and play facilities will be created as part of the multi-million-pound redevelopment.Now Aberdeen City Council’s culture spokeswoman Marie Boulton said she would like to see the visual arts company involved in plans for the area and hopes the cultural community will use spaces within the arches of the park.She said: “There’s going to be spaces in there which I’d like to see the cultural community take over and animate.“It would be great to have people in there doing art, making things.”Ms Boulton said exhibitions could be held in a building based close to the statue of Robert Burns.She said: “We could have dferent s in.“That will become a very animated space. We’ve got really exciting people in the city such as at Peacock Visual Arts.“I’d really like to see them come more to the front.“They were obviously meant to go into UTG and I’m sure there’s a conversation still to be had on that.“It’s really about making sure that we grow our talent base in the city, that they feel there’s an absolute reason to be in the city.”Work to transform the gardens began in August and is expected to finish in summer .

title: poundland submits plans aberdeen shopping centre store
story: A discount retailer is making plans to open in a former book shop on the city’s Union Street, The Evening Express can reveal.Poundland has applied for a building warrant from Aberdeen City Council to spend around £, on an internal fit-out of the former Waterstones retail store in the Trinity Centre.The prime city centre site has been lying vacant since the national bookseller moved from the store in May .Dustin Macdonald, chairman of the City Centre Community Council, said he was pleased to see the large unit occupied again.He said: “It’s good to see there’s still interest in Union Street property.“That shop has sat empty for a while and filling such a big unit can’t have been easy.”However, councillor Bill Cormie, who represents Rosemount, said: “We need to watch that Union Street doesn’t become a long mall of bookies and discount retailers.”The works would also include the installation of new stairs at ground to first floor level.Waterstones signed a -year lease in  for a two-storey unit in the Bon Accord Centre, Aberdeen.The Trinity Centre branch of the bookstore, which had long been a feature of Union Street, was previously occupied by another book store, Ottakar’s.Speaking at the time, bookshop manager Iain Dench said the Bon Accord Centre plan offered an “exciting prospect” for the business.Poundland has a store at  Union Street but it is not known whether this will be affected by the plan.The retailer also has shops in Berryden Retail Park, Inverurie and Elgin.The Trinity Centre and Poundland could not be reached for comment.

title: thank god we had niall to give us some quality says mcinnes
story: Boss Derek McInnes today praised Niall McGinn for battling through injury to net an equaliser at Tynecastle.McInnes confirmed the winger had been struggling with a muscle problem and only passed a late fitness test on the morning of the Premiership clash at Hearts.Pittodrie physios deemed the Northern Ireland winger was not fit enough to play for an entire  minutes.McInnes opted to name McGinn on the bench in the hope he could be introduced as an impact substitute.McGinn was brought on late in the first half as a replacement for Zak Vyner.On-loan Bristol City defender Vyner suffered a shoulder injury.Vyner will be assessed by a specialist and McInnes fears surgery may be required which could end the -year-old’s season.McGinn salvaged a - draw for the Reds against the Premiership’s bottom side with a superb free-kick.McInnes said: “Niall has been struggling with injury for the last few weeks.“He has had a little calf, hamstring thing.“It is a nerve thing that has affected his training.“Niall passed a fitness test on the day of the game but the phyisos said he didn’t have  minutes in him. He played  minutes against Livingstonwhen we only planned to play Niall for  minutes.“Niall did not have  minutes in him against Hearts but thank God we had him to call upon.“He has been doing that for years for us now, turning up when the game is screaming for a bit of quality. When we were screaming out for that quality, calmness and decision making Niall was there, as he normally is.”McGinn’s superb -yard free kick came immediately after Hearts had been reduced to  men.Sean Clare received a straight red for pulling back Jon Gallagher as the on-loan Atlanta United attacker broke in on goal.McGinn’s equaliser was the only moment of real attacking quality from Aberdeen. McInnes started with two strikers, Bruce Anderson and Curtis Main.McInnes said: “At half time we spoke with a bit of honesty about how we were not passing the ball well enough or showing enough of ourselves.“We were better when we went back to a more familiar shape with one up when Bruce went up on his own.“In the last  minutes of the game we were devoid of quality, calmness and the right decision making.“We all became a bit too rushed in what we were doing in sailing it forward and not moving the ball quick enough at times.“It was in these moments that we had to show a bit more experience, control and composure to get to their goal and get a winner.“Unfortunately we didn’t do enough to do that.”

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#
